Dear Ms. Vasilovski:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 05/31/2018.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan (ISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster homes.
One out of six licensing records reviewed did not comprehensively determine
compliance with licensing rules. A corrective action plan was noted for the
reevaluation though the citation was not cited within the report or 3080 foster home
compliance record.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One out of six applicable licensing records reviewed did not submit licensing
recommendations within 15 calendar days before the expiration of the license. The
license was to expire on 03/05/2018, whereas the recommendation was submitted
on 02/28/2018.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance or both of the following conditions exist:
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed. The
plan shall be in compliance with all of the following
requirements:
(iii) Be signed and dated by the foster parent and the
agency.
4

One out of six applicable licensing records did not contain the signature of the foster
parent on the corrective action plan.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(e) A list of all children currently placed in the home.
One out of three borrowed bed records reviewed did not contain a list of all children
currently placed in the home.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to
the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement
of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the
foster child and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency medical
care.
5

One out of six applicable foster care records reviewed did not provide the foster
parent with all the aforementioned information before placement. The foster child
was transferred from a DHHS home to an agency foster home on 09/20/2017. An
agency worker is noted as contacting the foster parent to discuss the placement on
09/21/2017 though cannot be determined if all the requirements were addressed. It
is also not that the DHHS 3307 - Initial Placement Outline was completed on
09/25/2017.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
One out of three adoption records reviewed contained an evaluation completed
beyond 90 days of the family signing the application. The preliminary application
was dated 02/22/2017, whereas the formal application was dated 02/24/2017. The
adoption evaluation was completed on 10/02/2017 and more than five months
beyond 90 days.
Repeat Citation from 04/21/2018Renewal Assessment
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 6.18 Page Relative Foster Parent Licensing, Timeliness (Commitment
23 54).
DHHS must license at least 85% of newly licensed relative
foster parents within 180 days of the date of placement.
The agency has three relative homes that are not licensed and they are beyond 180
days of placement. One relative home is pending denial, whereas a second is in the
process of denial. The third relative home is not motivated in submitting required
information.
Repeat Citation from 04/21/2018Renewal Assessment
ISEP 6.33(c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
Page 28
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
6

shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
One out eight applicable foster care cases reviewed did not contain the birth parent
signature on the updated service plan. It is noted that the birth parent’s rights were
terminated within the next report period.
Repeat Citation from 04/21/2018Renewal Assessment
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
SRM 200 CHRI Access to Authorized Individuals
All personnel requiring access to CW-CHRI must first be
deemed an authorized personnel. Authorized personnel are
individuals that are responsible for the licensing or approval of
foster and adoptive parents, clerical, and managerial staff who
support these functions and auditors/other vendors who have
been approved by MSP to view CW-CHRI. Prior to access of
CW-CHRI, authorized personnel must receive/complete the
following items and have them filed in his/her personnel record:
• ICHAT results.
• Successful completion of Security and Awareness training.
Two out of twenty-two employees contained security awareness training beyond six
months of hire. One employee training was three months late. The other
employee’s training was not late and also not documented through the State training
database due to the program not being contracted through the DHHS.
DHHS Policy Required Participation in Development - Foster Parent /
FOM 722-08C Caregiver
Page 2
The individual activities required by the foster parent/caregiver
to meet the specific individual needs of the child placed in their
home are included in the PATP. The foster parent/caregiver
must be included in the PATP process. The foster
parent/caregiver signature is required and indicates that the
foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and agrees to the
activities required to meet the needs of the child in their care.
Additionally, the PATP details the services and activities
provided by the foster care worker to assist the foster
parent/caregiver in caring for the child.
7

One out of eight foster care records reviewed did not contain the signature of the
foster parent on an updated service plan. It is noted that the foster parent signed the
other treatment plans reviewed during this reporting period.
Repeat Citation from 04/21/2018Renewal Assessment
DHHS Policy Unannounced Home Visit
FOM 722-6H –
Page 7
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in
the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If there are two
caregivers, such as a primary and secondary caregiver, the
caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the
secondary caregiver in the home at least once each quarter.
The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the home
every quarter. The unannounced visit must be documented in
MiSACWIS.
Two out of eight foster care records reviewed did not contain verification of
unannounced visits occurring for one quarter each. It is noted that monthly home
visits occurred in both cases reviewed.
Repeat Citation from 04/21/2018Renewal Assessment
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(f) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance or
noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
One out of four special evaluations reviewed noted a violation within the analysis
section of the report, though the box checked stated "Violation Not Established".
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
8

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were four incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The agency cited for behavior management and had the foster parents take
additional training, as well as review and sign the foster parent agency agreement
and behavior management policy. The corrective action plans were appropriate.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The 04/21/2017 renewal assessment resulted in a corrective action plan that
appropriately addressed the following as no repeat citations are noted: Borrowed
bed orientation and review of policies and procedures, verification of special
evaluations being given to case managers, updated physical examinations,
MiSACWIS implementation, quarterly medical passport signatures, documentation of
sibling and birth parent visits, semi-annual transition meetings, and timely letters of
intent. Repeat citations include: adoption assessments being completed within 90
days of signing the application, licensing relatives within 180 days of placement,
birth and foster parent signatures on treatment plans, and unannounced visits, which
all have decreased since the last review.
The analyst report dated 02/26/2018 reported no concerns or safety alerts.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
